node.title: Black Friday starts early, but expect fewer holiday deals
node.description: Poll shows Americans plan to spend an average of $886 on gifts this season, up slightly from last year.
node.content: ["Holiday shopping and Black Friday deals are already underway, with millions of Americans expected to hit stores and cruise for online discounts as they make up for lost time due to the COVID-19 pandemic.", "\"There's a bit of pent-up demand, as consumers are still saving money on not traveling and vacationing as much,\" retail analyst and consultant Neil Saunders told CBS MoneyWatch. \"There's also a determination to have a really good holiday, as last year was a bit of a washout.\"", "The National Retail Federation\u00a0forecasts\u00a0record holiday spending, predicting retail sales will jump more than 10% to $859 billion. Early signals already point to robust spending, with\u00a0sales climbing 1.7% last month\u00a0as people purchased fitness gear, electronics and clothing heading into the holidays.\u00a0", "On Black Friday, 64% are likely to shop in stores, up from 51% last year, a recently released NRF survey\u00a0found.", "Macy's\u00a0and\u00a0Walmart\u00a0were among those launching Black Friday sales in recent days, following\u00a0Target,\u00a0Best Buy\u00a0and other retailers moving up their holiday bargains. To that end,\u00a0Amazon\u00a0is kicking off its Cyber Monday deals on Saturday, November 27.\u00a0", "\"We have a Black Friday period rather than a Black Friday day,\" Saunders said. \"Consumers are out spending and keen to get into shops, and online will also be robust.\"", "While discounts are already in play, Saunders thinks there will be fewer bargains this year because of the product shortages caused by supply-chain disruptions. \"Inventory in thinner on the ground and demand is up,\" he said. \"You have to search harder for deals.\"\u00a0", "The appetite for holiday spending comes even as inflation has increased the price of many products. A Gallup\u00a0poll\u00a0out Tuesday found that Americans expect to spend an average of $886 on holiday gifts this year, slightly higher than last year.", "\"Many factors, most notably inflation and the pandemic, could influence how much consumers spend on gifts this season and where they ultimately shop,\" Gallup stated. \"But as of November, Americans intended to spend a fairly robust amount that should translate into solid holiday sales for the U.S. economy.\"", "For Breaking News & Analysis Download the Free CBS News app"]
